message: Today marks the beginning of the 115th Congress! For the last 6 years, my office has been located in the Cannon House Office Building. But with construction beginning this month in Cannon, we moved to 2446 Rayburn. If you are visiting DC and want to stop by the office, please come to Rayburn!

While 2017 has just begun, let's take a look back at 2016 and some of the accomplishments we achieved. I continued to fight the EPA on their regulatory overreach and voted on legislation to rein in the IRS. Please watch the video below to learn more.

When Elie Wiesel passed away last year, a book of letters mourning his death and honoring his legacy was produced. I was honored to contribute to this project. He will be missed but never forgotten, as his work and activism will impact many generations to come.

I was happy to speak with The Daily Record, Wooster, OH's Bobby Warren about the start of the 115th Congress and what issues I'm looking forward to tackling with President-elect Trump after he is sworn in on January 20th.

Last year, the United Nations Security Council passed an outrageous resolution that condemns our ally Israel. Shockingly, the United States, which could have prevented the adoption of the resolution by vetoing it, abstained. This allowed the resolution to pass. Today, the House will be voting on a resolution of our own to formally object to the UN Security Council resolution. Israel is an important ally in an unstable region and a democratic nation. Our friends and allies across the world need to know that we will support them.

Earlier this week, my friend and former District Director Darrell Kick was sworn in as State Representative for Ohio's 70th House District. I want to congratulate Darrell on his next adventure and wish him luck in Columbus!
Please take a minute today to thank the men and women who keep our neighborhoods safe.

Last night, we passed the HALOS Act, which lowers regulatory barriers for start-up companies to connect with angel investors. Companies like Google, Facebook, and Amazon began as startups seeking early investments. New SEC rules currently make it difficult for startups and potential investors to talk at what are called "demo days". Government regulations should make it EASIER for new and growing companies to find investors, not harder.

One of the most important things we have to tackle in the 115th Congress is regulatory reform. The rule making power of government bureaucracies has become what I call a hidden branch of government. Reforming not just individual regulations, but the way those rules are developed, finalized, and implemented is critical in unleashing the entrepreneurial and innovative spirit of the American economy. You can read more about what we have done to reduce regulatory burdens in my op-ed at The Daily Caller.

The Ashland University Lady Eagles are ranked #1! One of their players is Alexandra Henning, who was an intern in my office last year. We miss Alex but are proud of her accomplishments on and off the court!

Since Obamacare went into effect, the American people have experienced the consequences of this failed law.  Millions of Americans have seen their insurance plans canceled. Millions more are forced to pay double-digit increases in their premiums every year.  Despite President Obama’s promises that ‘if you like your doctor, you can keep your doctor’, many Americans forced to purchase health insurance through the Obamacare exchanges were turned away by their physicians.  Today’s vote is the first step to repealing Obamacare, stopping its taxes and mandates, and returning health care decisions to patients and doctors rather than government bureaucrats. Obamacare must be replaced with market-oriented reforms that actually lowers costs, provides more options, and strengthens the patient-doctor relationship.
Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. committed his life to peace and equality under the law. Today, our nation celebrates and honors his legacy.

This morning, the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee will hold a hearing on the nomination of Oklahoma Attorney General Scott Pruitt to EPA Administrator. Attorney General Pruitt is a fantastic choice and will restore the collaborative relationship between the EPA and state agencies in enforcing the Clean Water Act. I'm looking forward to his confirmation hearing.

Just one more day until Inauguration! If you are visiting DC for the event, click on the link below to find plenty of information about the ceremony, a map of the event, and items you are and are not allowed to bring with you to the National Mall.
In just 90 minutes, President-elect Trump will take the Oath of Office, completing another peaceful transfer of power in our Republic.

A lot of people on the National Mall today for President Trump's inauguration. I snapped this photo before the ceremony began. Seeing so many Americans come together to celebrate today, I was struck by a particular line from the President's speech:  "...today we are not merely transferring power from one administration to another, or from one party to another -- but we are transferring power from Washington, D.C. and giving it back to you, the American People."  It's time roll up our sleeves, get back to work, and empower the American people, not bureaucrats.
A few more photos from the Inauguration of President Trump.

ICYMI - Over the weekend, cleveland.com ran my op-ed in support of Scott Pruitt, President Trump's pick to head the EPA. Pruitt is a fantastic choice to run the agency. He has the skills, personal background, and governing philosophy to ensure the EPA works as a partner with states, rather than deferring to a radical activist ideology like EPA did in the Obama Administration.  I encourage Senators Portman and Brown to confirm Scott Pruitt as EPA Administrator.
Coshocton Mayor Steve Mercer gave his State of the City address last night. Mayor Mercer has been doing a great job and I look forward to seeing Coshocton continue to grow with his steady leadership!
I applaud President Trump for his actions today moving the Keystone XL and Dakota Access pipelines forward. These are important projects for the American economy.

Today, the House approved the No Taxpayer Funding For Abortion Act. As a Christian, a father, and a grandfather, I know how precious each and every life is.  It is our responsibility to speak for and defend those who cannot speak for themselves. Since 1976, the Hyde Amendment has saved the lives of 2 million unborn children, preventing taxpayer dollars from being used to fund or provide abortions through Medicaid and other services. Unfortunately, Obamacare has circumvented the Hyde Amendment by directing taxpayer funds towards premium assistance for insurance plans that cover abortion. By expanding the Hyde Amendment’s reach and making it permanent, we can protect more lives from abortion and ensure taxpayers are in no way, directly or indirectly, financially responsible for abortion procedures.  No American should be forced to violate their deeply-held personal beliefs, and H.R. 7 will make sure that does not happen.

Earlier this week my district staff attended the Tuscarawas County Chamber of Commerce's annual awards banquet. It was a packed house! The Chamber recognized Jan McInturf and Jeff Mathias, both local realtors, for their dedication to Tuscarawas County as mentors and community leaders. Congratulations to Jeff and Jan!

Thank you to British Prime Minister Theresa May for addressing the House and Senate GOP today in Philadelphia. I am looking forward to working with you and President Trump to solidify our two nations' Special Relationship.

Thank you President Donald J. Trump for speaking to the House and Senate Republicans earlier today. We will work together to repeal and replace Obamacare, reform our regulatory and tax structure, secure our border, and Make America Great Again!

Earlier this week, I spoke on the House floor about the need for major reforms to our regulatory state, true tax reform that unleashes our entrepreneurial spirit, and repeals and replaces Obamacare with free market-based principles that actually lowers costs while ensuring that no one falls through the cracks.

Yesterday, the President released an Executive Order that aims to cut the regulatory overreach by federal agencies. Over the years, the regulatory and rule-making power of the executive branch has slowly grown, leading to unsustainable compliance costs and confusing mandates. This is a good step in the right direction. But we must also reform the way rules and regulations are written in the first place. The regulatory state has become a hidden fourth branch of government, writing de facto laws. It's time to rebalance the Constitutional separation of powers and ensure those elected to represent the people have final approval on major rules that can have devastating impacts on our economy.

My statement on the nomination of Judge Neil Gorsuch for the US Supreme Court:  Neil Gorsuch will make an outstanding Supreme Court Justice. His judicial philosophy appears to be in line with the late Justice Scalia and he takes a strict interpretation of the Constitution. President Trump demonstrated his commitment to the principle of religious liberty by selecting Gorsuch. I look forward to seeing Judge Gorsuch confirmed by the Senate as soon as possible.
I was proud to speak in support of H.J. Res 38 to disapprove of the so-called "Stream Protection Rule", which can have disastrous consequences on Ohio's coal industry.

It's an honor to be at the 65th Annual National Prayer Breakfast. There's been several amazing speakers leading the group in thoughtful prayer. Senate Chaplain and Rear Admiral (Ret.) Barry C. Black was insightful and funny.

My district staff attended the Richland Community Development Group's meeting this morning. They heard from Ontario Mayor Randy Hutchinson on the economic development projects and goals for the City of Ontario.

Canton Mayor Tom Bernabei gave his State of the City Address this morning. It's great to see the partnership with the Pro Football Hall of Fame continue. My staff was on hand to hear about the Mayor's accomplishments and future capital improvement projects.

Last night, the House passed HR 244, the HIRE Vets Act. It directs the Department of Labor to create a voluntary program through which businesses in the private sector are recognized for hiring men and women who wore our nation's uniform. Their duty was to protect and defend America and the Constitution. It is our duty to ensure they have career opportunities after they complete their service.
Thank you to Dave Dilly, a constituent and member of the United Mine Workers of America for stopping by to talk about the energy and healthcare issues important to the mining industry.

When it comes to our national parks and federal recreational lands, the right to protect yourself is not always uniformly applied. While Americans can carry concealed firearms on NPS and Fish and Wildlife lands when state law permits, Army Corps recreation lands are excluded. That's why I introduced the Recreational Lands Self-Defense Act, which allows law-abiding citizens permitted for concealed-carry according to their state laws to exercise their #SecondAmendment rights on Army Corps recreational lands.

Congratulations to Akron-Canton Airport (CAK) for the completion of the new covered parking area. CAK has seen some tremendous infrastructure improvements recently and continues to be an organization that prides itself on fantastic customer service.

Congratulations to the Oakwood Middle School's Future City Team for their victory at the regional Future City competition last month. They were in DC this weekend for the national finals. The team also toured the Capitol, where each student received a copy of the Congressional Record honoring their achievements!

I had a great time today at the Rotary Club of Plain Township's Youth Leadership Conference with students from GlenOak and Central Catholic. They had excellent questions. I always enjoy getting to meet the next generation of our country's leaders.

Earlier today, I met with a group of constituents from Stark County who voiced their concerns about health care reform. We didn't agree on everything but the overall discussion was informative and constructive. I value the input of all constituents and I will continue to meet with groups who request a meeting.

Thank you to ProVia for the invitation to tour your facility and the chance to speak with your employees. Manufacturers like ProVia are what keeps our economy moving forward. We can't continue to place more burdens on those who create and sustain jobs for so many Americans. Too many Americans and businesses have been hit hard by the skyrocketing premiums and deductibles year after year under Obamacare. We have to repeal and replace it with a plan that actually drives down costs with increased competition in the market and that does not allow anyone to fall through the cracks, ensuring pre-existing conditions are covered, lifetime caps are removed, and that young Americans can stay on their parents' plans until they're 26 years old. The transition from Obamacare must be stable and smooth so that everyone, from patients to doctors to insurers, are prepared.

I was happy to join Extreme Trailers in Dover on Friday for their ribbon cutting. This is a new company specializing in flatbed trailer design and manufacturing. Congratulations to Extreme Trailer and to the city of Dover for continuing to support its business community.

Will you join me tomorrow night on Facebook Live at 7:30PM? I will be online to answer all of your questions (and I do mean ALL questions).  If you're a constituent in the 7th District and would like to have your question answered, please comment below and I will make sure it is answered tomorrow night at 7:30!

I was honored to attend today’s signing of the Executive Order directing the EPA and Army Corps of Engineers to stop the WOTUS Rule. When the EPA wrote this flawed regulation, they ignored key comments from the Army Corps, expanded their jurisdiction against the instructions from previous court decisions, and broke the law in promoting the rule on social media. We can protect the environment, encourage economic growth, and safeguard private property rights without unnecessarily expanding federal jurisdiction and stopping the WOTUS rule is the first step in achieving those three objectives.  Last year, I urged President Trump to take action on WOTUS. Today, he is fulfilling a promise he made and making good on his pledge to reduce and reform regulations that are hurting everyday Americans. As I said yesterday, farmers in Ohio and across the nation cannot afford more costly and burdensome regulations from a Washington bureaucracy that thinks it knows best.

Last night, President Trump laid out a bold and positive vision for America. His remarks speak to the very heart of the issues facing so many Americans every day: keeping communities safe, making sure jobs stay in America, and honoring our obligations to the men and women who served in the U.S. Armed Forces.  We have an incredible opportunity to reform the way Washington works, rebuild our military, and secure our borders. Most importantly, we will work with President Trump to repeal and replace Obamacare. Millions of Americans have been hurt by Obamacare: their premiums and deductibles have skyrocketed, their plans were canceled, and their previous doctors can no longer see them.  Whether it’s regulatory relief for American businesses and non-profits, meaningful tax reform that works for American families, or increasing access to a quality education to make the American Dream possible for every child, I look forward to working with President Trump in moving our nation forward.

Today, the House voted on the Regulatory Integrity Act. This legislation will require agencies to publish info about proposed rules and regulations online and submit annual reports to Congress on agencies' regulatory actions. It will also prevent executive agencies from publicly advocating for proposed regulatory actions. Two years ago, the EPA broke the law by using social media to promote and advocate for their Waters of the United States Rule without disclosing it.  Federal agencies cannot become a hidden fourth branch of government. We have to reform the rule-making process to make it more transparent and accountable.

Thank you to the FBI for their investigation and today’s arrest in some of the recent threats against Jewish Community Centers.  These threats, and the vandalism of Jewish cemeteries across the nation, are repulsive and I stand with the Jewish community in rejecting them.  Attacks and threats like these have no place in America.

The weather was perfect this morning to speak with a group of students from the Christian Community School on the steps of the Capitol. It's always a pleasure to meet with school groups when they visit Washington!

Yesterday, I spoke on the House floor to share Melanie's story.  Since Obamacare was enacted, she's faced increased premiums and her deductible has skyrocketed. Melanie and her husand are near retirement. When her husband was laid off, they burned through their savings to keep their health insurance and could not find a reasonably priced option on the Obamacare exchange. When she needed an affordable option in an emergency, it wasn't there.  Obamacare broke it's promise to Melanie and millions of Americans.

The top priority of the federal government is the safety of the American people and the security of our nation. Last night, I was proud to join an overwhelmingly bipartisan group in the House to pass legislation providing the necessary resources for the men and women in uniform to do achieve that priority.  Not only does this legislation maintain troop readiness for combat and peacetime missions, but it makes important investments in research and development to combat and deter future threats.  Most importantly, we are investing directly in our military personnel, retired personnel, and their families with a 2.1% pay raise and increased funding for the Defense Health Program.  We owe it to those who risk their lives in defense of America to make sure they receive the pay and care they deserve.

BIG thanks to Speaker Paul Ryan, Rep Greg Walden, Rep. Larry Bucshon, and Rep Brad Wenstrup for addressing the county farm bureau presidents from Ohio earlier today. We had a great discussion about the agriculture industry, health care, trade, and many other topics. Thank you to Ohio Farm Bureau Federation for making the trek to D.C. and letting us know how we can help keep Ohio and American agriculture strong.

The Great Lakes Commission is in Washington this week and I had the opportunity to speak to their membership this morning. It's important that we recognize the role the Great Lakes play in our environment and our economy. Programs like the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative provide the resources to keep our lakes healthy and prosperous.

Earlier today, my staff attended the grand opening of the United Way of Greater Stark County's new Financial Prosperity Center. It is a collaboration with Ohio Means Jobs to provide financial literacy courses and other assistance for the community.

Please join me Monday evening for a telephone townhall. If you're a constituent and would like to participate, please click on the link below to send me an email with your phone number indicating you want to be called and we'll make sure you will be included.
Thank you to everyone who signed up for tonight's telephone townhall. Those who signed up with a phone number will receive a call around 7:30 this evening.

I was proud to receive US Chamber's Spirit of Enterprise Award this morning! I believe that by empowering Americans and encouraging our nation's entrepreneurial spirit, we can put America on a path of prosperity. A robust and growing private sector that offers opportunities for all Americans is essential to our future.
It gets busy here in Washington when we're in session, but I'm glad to be able to spend some time with family and see my grandson!

Today is #NationalAgDay! Ohio's agriculture industry is among the best in the world. Buckeye farmers are earnest custodians of our land. They grow our fruits, grains, and vegetables and raise the livestock we all depend on to keep our families healthy!

I was happy to address the US Water Alliance this afternoon! Water infrastructure is not a partisan issue. We can work with local partners to ensure the drinking and wastewater needs of our communities can be met.

It is truly an honor to win the Waterways Council, Inc.'s 2017 Leadership Service Award.  Our nation's infrastructure doesn't stop at roads and bridges. Our economy and our environment relies on a safe and reliable inland waterway network. I am proud to continue working with the Waterways Council, the Army Corps of Engineers, and local stakeholders to ensure our nation's water transportation infrastructure needs are met.

It was an honor to recognize Jane Roland from the Ashland County Veterans Service Office on Saturday evening. Jane has been nominated several times for the Medal of Honor Society, which recognizes civilians for their service to others. I've known Jane for many years. She is one of the best advocates for veterans and veterans services in Ohio and I recognized her for her commitment to vets last year in our Women's History Month series. I am proud to call Jane a friend!
I was happy to meet with a group of great Ohioans in town for AIPAC's annual policy conference. We must remain committed to the safety and security of Israel, our greatest ally in the Middle East.
Thank you to the Ohio Restaurant Association for stopping by this morning! We had a great discussion on issues important to the food industry.

Here's a great #TBT for today. Last year, I helped my colleague Rep. Dave Joyce in passing his bill, the Great Lakes Rstoriation Initiative Act of 2016. The Great Lakes region supports over $200 billion in economic activity and is one of the world’s largest sources of freshwater. The GLRI focuses on critical issues like protecting water quality and stopping invasive species that threaten the Great Lakes ecosystem. Thank you, Dave, for introducing this bill and sharing my goal to keep the Great Lakes open for business.
Congratulations to the Ashland Eagles Women's Basketball Team for winning the National Championship, capping off a perfect season!

Congratulations to Richland County Sheriff Steve Sheldon for his office's  recognition by the Commission of Accreditation for Law Enforcement Agencies. Sheriff Sheldon, his deputies and staff work tirelessly every day to protect the people of Richland County and to carry out their duty in a professional and responsible manner.

Last year, we ran a People's Choice Award for the Congressional Art Competition for the first time.  It went so well, we're doing it again this year! We received 40 submissions for this year's art competition. Please LIKE (not Love, Laugh, or Angry) your favorite submission. The submission with the most likes will win the 2017 People's Choice Award!  The deadline to like your favorite is April 19th at 5PM. The total likes will then be tallied and the winner will be announced! Good luck to all participants

Yesterday, the House Agriculture Committee  held a hearing on the impacts of tax policy on the Ag industry. As tax reform is debated, I believe it's important to remember that American agriculture is going through a generational change and that the tax code, specifically estate taxes, can have a negative impact on multi-generational family farming.
Neil Gorsuch will be an outstanding Associate Justice. He has proven himself to be a qualified and thoughtful jurist. Congratulations, Justice Gorsuch!
I am grateful for the invitation from the Public Employee Retirees to speak with their group at lunch today. We had a productive conversation about pensions and health care reform.

I was able to visit Invacare in Lorain County this afternoon to tour their showroom and manufacturing facility, as well as speak with a group of Invacare employees. They make medical equipment that aids in mobility, respiratory therapy, and personal care. American companies like Invacare are the leading edge in medical innovation.

Just one week left to vote for this year's Congressional Art Competition People's Choice Award.  Please browse through the submissions below and LIKE your favorites. The submission with the most likes will win the People's Choice Award!

Yesterday my staff was on hand to present Army veteran Richard Biedenbach with a copy of the Congressional Record honoring his dedication to his community and fellow veterans. Last year, Richard was named Veteran of the Year by the Greater Canton Veterans Council for his continued commitment to improving the lives of veterans. He volunteers his time to transport Stark County veterans to and from the VA clinic in Canton. Thank you, Mr. Biedenbach for your service!

I had meetings in my Ashland office yesterday afternoon with constituents concerned about health care, national security, and immigration. We won't always see eye to eye on many topics but I am glad we were able to discuss these important issues. As a reminder, my offices will be closed today to celebrate the Easter weekend. I hope everyone gets to enjoy the holiday with their families and friends.

I enjoyed discussing important issues like health care, tax reform, and the budget with constituents in Tuscarawas County today. Thank you very much to Scott Robinson and everyone at the Tuscarawas County Chamber of Commerce for hosting the event.

Proud to stand with my friend, State Representative Al Landis, in support of the #GotYourBack campaign. It is vitally important that we take the time to talk with those around us about the dangers of drugs. By standing together, we can all make a difference.

Today I toured CommQuest in Massillon with my friends, Senator Portman and Commissioner Creighton. Stark County is tackling the drug fight by utilizing wrap around services and great community collaborations. Confronting and defeating opioid addiction is critical to ensuring a better life for the next generation of Americans, and I am committed to succeeding in this fight. Only through a comprehensive approach that leverages evidence-based law enforcement and health care services, including treatment – like those contained in the Comprehensive Addiction Recovery Act - can we stop and reverse current trends.
NA

I enjoyed meeting with constituents in Louisville this morning to discuss cystic fibrosis issues. We have come a long way in research but we have more work to do. Thanks to this wonderful family for taking time to speak with me today.

Congratulations to our Congressional Art Show People’s Choice Award Winner: Avaerie Fitzgerald from Ashland High School! Very impressed by your talent and by all of the amazing art work we are seeing all over the 7th Congressional District.

I had a very productive conversation with business and community leaders in Canton today about current legislative issues. It is vital that we get our economy moving again. We can achieve that goal through regulatory and tax reform. Thank you very much to the Canton Regional Chamber of Commerce for hosting us!
I enjoyed my visit with Parksite, a great company in Louisville. Businesses like yours vital to a growing economy. Thank you very much for taking the time to visit with me!

It was great meeting constituents at last night's Massillon WestStark Chamber of Commerce annual dinner. I enjoyed hearing from the small business community about how we get Washington D.C. out of their way.   I have had many great conversations during constituent meetings, business tours, roundtable table discussions and speaking engagements over the past two weeks. I look forward to taking these great ideas back to Washington D.C. next week as I work on behalf of the 7th Congressional District.

Earlier today, my staff was on-hand for the Curio by Hilton hotel groundbreaking ceremony at the Johnson Controls Hall of Fame Village. Congratulations to David Baker and the entire HOF team for their continuing efforts to make Canton and Stark County a premiere destination for people to live, work, and visit.

On Monday evening, the The Coburn Gallery, Ashland University hosted a reception for the finalists in this year's Congressional Art Competition. We announced the first, second, and third place winners as well as the People's Choice winner! Congratulations to Sarah Gillum from Plymouth High School, this year's winner! Her artwork, titled "Unmasked" will be on display for a year in the Art Competition Gallery on Capitol Hill. Peter Zimmerman came in second place, Willow Cox won third place, and Avaerie Fitzgerald won the People's Choice Award!  We have so many talented young artists in Ohio and I always enjoy reviewing the entries for the Art Competition. Sarah, Peter, Willow, Avaerie, and all students who participated should be very proud of their accomplishment. The creative arts are an important component to a well-rounded education and helps exercise other parts of the mind that physical education and studies may not.  I am looking forward to seeing these artists’ works on display in Washington and Ashland.

Earlier today I held a conference call with county veterans service offices and representatives from the VA to discuss some of the reforms we're passing in Congress to provide better care and service to our nation's veterans. Among the topics discussed were the Veterans Choice Program, which allows vets to see a doctor of their choice in certain circumstances. I believe it's a moral responsibility to provide the best care to those who served in uniform.

Congratulations to Rick McQueen and his team at the Akron-Canton Airport (CAK) for celebrating the inaugural non-stop flight to Las Vegas yesterday! CAK is an important partner in growing Ohio's economy.
Congrats to AU's Adam Sheehan for being drafted by the Chicago Bears in the NFL Draft!

Yesterday kicked off Small Business Week! Keep an eye out for information from the Small Business Administration over the next few days. Also, be sure to follow House Small Business Committee for more resources!

Congratulations to SARTA Operators Jim McClone, Kathy Yoder, William Hall, and Darryal Williams for winning the Transit Operator of the Year Awards at the Annual Ohio Public Transit Association conference.  Not only is SARTA on the cutting edge of tech research in public transportation, but they have an incredible team of people that make it a great organization.
Did you miss this weekend's E-newsletter? Fear not! It's available online! You can read it by clicking the link below!

Thank you to recently sworn-in Secretary of Agriculture Sonny Perdue for taking action to give schools flexibility in providing nutritious and appetizing meals for students. I join the School Nutrition Association in urging a commonsense plan that allows school lunches to be the fuel needed for students to learn and grow.
Continuing Small Business Week, SBA Administrator Linda McMahon was live on Facebook answering questions on starting and growing a business.  You can watch the video below.

Today I voted for the American Health Care Act. It is clear that Obamacare is collapsing, with news just this week of insurers exiting several state's individual exchanges.  There are a lot of concerns about if and how the AHCA will affect Americans with pre-existing conditions.  Below is a video to explain a few key points that shows protections for those Americans will continue.

Since I first got to Congress, one of my top priorities has been to get rid of Obamacare. Today, I voted to provide relief to the millions of Americans impacted by Obamacare’s individual mandate, its taxes and penalties, and the regulations that have driven up insurance costs for so many Americans. Obamacare is collapsing and the American people are suffering because of it. We cannot afford the status quo with premiums set to skyrocket again next year and insurance companies continuing to pull out of exchanges, leaving Americans with fewer options.  This bill continues the process of repealing and replacing Obamacare with a plan that lowers costs, increases choices, and gets rid of the individual mandate.  Introducing free market principles and incentivizing the use of Health Savings Accounts (HSAs) is an effective way to lower costs and return the power of healthcare decision-making to patients. This bill expands on the ability to use HSAs, continues protections for Americans with pre-existing conditions, and provides support for states to create high risk pools to help low-income Americans afford health care. It also boosts funding for hospitals that have a high proportion of Medicaid and Medicare patients.  Today’s vote is one more step in the right direction but the effort to repeal Obamacare is not over. I urge the Senate to take up this legislation, debate it, and work with the House to  provide relief for Americans from Obamacare’s broken promises.

This is great news in our efforts to keep Lake Erie healthy and safe!  Lake Erie is one of Ohio's most precious and important natural resources. Many lakeshore communities rely on it for clean and affordable drinking water and the lake plays a key role in Ohio's economy. For the last few years, I have been working with the Ohio EPA to prevent the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers from dumping dredged sediment from the Cuyahoga River that contains contaminants called polychlorinated biphenyls, or PCBs, into Lake Erie. Elevated PCB levels can lead to contamination among the lake’s fish populations.  I'm very happy to see this result!
If you're looking for a new opportunity, please stop by the Job Fair at the Monroe Center in New Philadelphia this Thursday! Over 70 employers will be there!

I was happy to visit Zimmer Biomet in Dover this morning. Zimmer is a medical device manufacturer that focuses on restoring and increasing mobility for patients. They do some incredible work and companies like Zimmer are why America leads the world in medical innovation.

Don't forget to attend today's Job Fair in Tuscarawas County! Over 70 employers will be there. So stop by the Monroe Center in New Philadelphia from 11AM to 2PM with your résumé if you are looking for a new career opportunity! Thank you to WJER Radio, the Tuscarawas County Chamber of Commerce, Goodwill Industries of Greater Cleveland and East Central Ohio, Inc., and Ohio Means Jobs Centers in Stark and Tuscarawas Counties for helping organize this great event.

I greatly enjoyed visiting with constituents today at the Job Fair in Tuscarawas County! Nearly 80 businesses participated. Thank again to WJER Radio, the Tuscarawas County Chamber of Commerce, Goodwill Industries of Greater Cleveland and East Central Ohio, Inc., and Ohio Means Jobs Centers in Stark and Tuscarawas Counties for all of your hard work organizing the event.

I appreciated the chance to visit the VA Outpatient Clinic in New Philadelphia. Supporting our veterans is critical. Thank you Susan Fuehrer, Kim Robertson, and Whitney Waseity for taking the time to speak with me about the services being provided in New Philadelphia, Tuscarawas County, and the rest of the 7th Congressional District.

Terrible news out of Licking County this morning. Kirkersville's Chief of Police, Steven Disario, was killed in the line of duty while responding to an active shooter situation. Chief Disario was only on the job for three weeks. Please keep his family as well as the families of others killed in this tragedy in your prayers.

Last week I got to stop by and tour a project from the West Holmes Building and Trade program. These students worked with their teacher Dave McMillen to build a home and hone their construction and trade skills. The home will be sold at auction later this month. This program teaches students practical skills in the building trades and sees most if not all of its graduates placed into technical schools or straight into employment. Congratulations to Dave and his students for this incredible achievement!

I'll be hosting a live phone forum tomorrow at 5PM.  While we will be calling out to many households in the district, if you want to ensure you get called, please click on the link below and fill out the form.  Note: You MUST sign up by 12 NOON on MAY 16th to be included in the call. You can ask your question in the form and we'll do our best to get to as many questions as possible.  We'll also be taking live questions and a few questions from Facebook.
We're starting our live phone forum at 5PM. You can listen in by clicking on the link below.

It is National Police Week. The men and women in blue risk their lives every day to keep our communities safe. Every so often, a mother or a father in uniform does not make it home after their shift.  Last week, the police chief of Kirkersville,  Steven DiSario was killed in the line of duty. Last year, Danville, Ohio experienced the loss of Officer Thomas Cottrell and Canton Police Department lost K9 Officer Jethro. During National Police Week, please pray for the families of those we lost and for the continued safety of those currently serving as police and peace officers.

My staff was in attendance this afternoon at the North Ridgeville Chamber of Commerce & Visitor's Bureau lunch to hear from Dr James Powell, Superintendent of North Ridgeville Schools about updates from the school. They toured the new Academic Center and heard about the great achievements of North Ridgeville students.

Congratulations to the Village of Zoar for its recent designation as a National Historic Landmark. Good to see my friend State Representative Al Landis at the ceremony this morning. I also had the opportunity to meet to German Consul General on Chicago, Herbert Quelle, who was on hand to celebrate, as Zoar's history is tied to German immigrants. Also pictured is a brick honoring the late Mayor Larry Bell, a dedicated public servant who cared deeply for the village. His wife Valerie was on hand. Congratulations to Zoar on this great honor.
I was honored to join the Friends of Waggoner Cemetery this weekend for a service honoring the men and women who died while serving our nation in uniform.

Later today the House will be voting on my bipartisan bill, the Reducing Regulatory Burdens Act. This is important legislation that fixes a bad court decision requiring a costly, unnecessary, and duplicative permit when cities and municipalities use pesticides already approved and regulated by the EPA for mosquito abatement. It's just another layer of red tape that diverts resources from their mission of protecting the public from insect borne diseases.

Last night I had the opportunity to attend the Twilight Tattoo at Fort Meyer featuring the 3rd US Infantry Regiment and the US Army Band. It was an incredible show! Also attending were students from Black River, Crestview, and New London! The Twilight Tattoo occurs every Wednesday through August 9th and is open to the public. If you'll be in DC during then, I highly recommend it!
As we celebrate Memorial Day, may we also remember and honor those who gave the ultimate sacrifice in service to our great nation.

President Trump did the right thing by pulling out of the non-binding Paris Accord. America has an abundance of energy resources and we shouldn't make it more difficult for Ohio families that rely on affordable energy to make ends meet. This agreement would cost American jobs, cost our economy trillions, and have little to no real impact on the environment.

Yesterday's attack in London is a reminder of the constant threat of radical Islamic terrorism. We must be vigilant in defeating those willing to attack innocent civilians in the name of a hateful ideology. The United States will never waver in our commitment to defend against Islamic extremism, and we stand with our friends and allies in the U.K.
On the Paris Climate Agreement

How many times does this have to happen before Democrats concede that Obamacare is an absolute and total failure? This is further evidence that government mandates, taxes, and penalties make it more difficult to provide Americans with reliable and affordable health insurance.  Nearly one quarter of Ohio’s counties will be left with no options on the individual market, including 3 counties from Ohio’s Seventh District.  This news is outrageous, yet sadly, not a surprise.  Obamacare, state by state, has been restricting options for millions of Americans.  Now is the time to repeal Obamacare and replace it with plan centered on market-based principles that actually drives down the cost of health care. We have to bring certainty and peace of mind back to those who have suffered needlessly.  If you are a resident of Coshocton, Holmes, or Knox County and have concerns about how this news affects your insurance coverage, please call my Washington office at 202-225-6265.

From the Desk of General Dwight D. Eisenhower, June 6, 1944:  Soldiers, Sailors, and Airmen of the Allied Expeditionary Force:  You are about to embark upon the Great Crusade, toward which we have striven these many months.  The eyes of the world are upon you. The hopes and prayers of liberty-loving people everywhere march with you.  In company with our brave Allies and brothers-in-arms on other Fronts you will bring about the destruction of the German war machine, the elimination of Nazi tyranny over oppressed peoples of Europe, and security for ourselves in a free world.  Your task will not be an easy one. Your enemy is well trained, well equipped, and battle-hardened. He will fight savagely.  But this is the year 1944. Much has happened since the Nazi triumphs of 1940-41. The United Nations have inflicted upon the Germans great defeats, in open battle, man-to-man. Our air offensive has seriously reduced their strength in the air and their capacity to wage war on the ground. Our Home Fronts have given us an overwhelming superiority in weapons and munitions of war, and placed at our disposal great reserves of trained fighting men. The tide has turned. The free men of the world are marching together to victory.  I have full confidence in your courage, devotion to duty, and skill in battle. We will accept nothing less than full victory.  Good Luck! And let us all beseech the blessing of Almighty God upon this great and noble undertaking.

Earlier today, the President spoke in Cincinnati to address the needs of our nation's inland waterways infrastructure. He is right that we need smart investments to ensure the projects vital to keeping the rivers that power our economy flowing.  This is a BIPARTISAN issue, one which I've worked with my colleagues on the other side of the aisle to implement meaningful reforms to streamline the study and approval process. These reforms started when the House passed the Water Resources Reform and Development passed the House 417-3!
I had a great meeting this afternoon with the Ohio Electric Cooperative Youth Tour! What an impressive group of engaged and motivated students. We talked about civic engagement and public service.

On this day in 1777, the Continental Congress adopted the stars and stripes as the flag of the United States . The flag has changed over the years as we added states but it still flies as a symbol of freedom.

After the tragic events of this week, here is Reverend Patrick J. Conroy's opening prayer from June 14th:  “Almighty God, on a day when violence has come to this assembly, we ask your blessing on our brother, Representative Steve Scalise, the two officers and the staffer who have been shot. Bless the hands of those who tend to their injuries.    “We as Americans are blessed by a free and open society with rights secured by law and the Constitution. But once again, we’re reminded that there is a vulnerability that comes with that openness.    “May we all be vigilant in being good citizens, neighbors, and defenders of our way of life at a time when so many challenges to our way of life and government seem under siege. We thank you for the men and women who respond to the crises that befall us, especially the Capitol Police, and all first responders. May their heroism and generosity of spirit be an inspiration to us all, and may they be assured of our appreciation of their service.    “And in this great silence, as we are gathered most dramatically as this assembly, the People’s House, may Republicans and Democrats be mindful of the rare companionship they share. Men and women who have taken very public responsibility for our country, that carries so many burdens and today the reminder of shared danger.    “May this day be characterized by kindness, goodwill, and compassion, one to another. God, bless America. And may all that is done this day be for your greater honor and glory. Amen.”

I was honored to make a few remarks last night at the FATHERS Motorcycle Poker Run, an event that raised awareness for those impacted by the opioid epidemic. Hundreds of people participated throughout the day. If we are going to overcome this crisis, we must view and treat it holistically and at every level. Families and communities need support for finding addiction treatment while we make sure law enforcement has the resources to arrest and prosecute criminals peddling heroin and pharmacies work with the DEA to monitor and thwart narcotics trafficking.

I was happy to be on hand for MCTV's Excellerate announcement. This is an exciting development that will bring high-speed fiber internet capabilities to many in the Stark County area. Building out the "last mile" of internet infrastructure is critical in ensuring Americans have access to high speed internet service.
I was happy to be on hand for this announcement. Access to high speed internet is critical in giving Ohio businesses an edge in e-commerce.
Earlier today my staff was in Mount Vernon to celebrate the opening of the Knox Community Hospital Hull Business Center. It will house the hospital's offices in downtown Mount Vernon!
It was great to talk to members of the Ohio Propane Gas Association yesterday and discuss issues important to them and their customers.

Thank you to the National Association of Manufacturers for the NAM Award for Manufacturing Legislative Excellence. I am proud to stand with you and your members to make sure Washington does what is right for American workers and manufacturers.

Congratulations to New Philadelphia for yesterday's ribbon cutting is their new fire station. My office was on hand to celebrate and provide a proclamation celebrating the city's commitment to public safety!

It was an honor to speak in Huron County Saturday evening at The Wall That Heals, a traveling replica of the Vietnam Veterans Memorial. There were many who didn't make it home from Vietnam. It's important to honor them and this traveling exhibit gives their fellow soldiers and families the opportunity to do so if they cannot make the trip to DC.

I was disappointed to learn the Senate will not be taking up health care reform and the repeal of Obamacare this week. Obamacare is imploding: as many as 20 counties in Ohio will not have an option on the individual market next year while premiums continue to increase across the board. We have to get this done to help the millions of Americans who are facing canceled coverage, increased premiums and deductibles, or can no longer see their doctor. Coshocton, Holmes, and Knox Counties will have no plans on the exchange next year if we don't act.
Happy Independence Day!

Informative tour of the Onesta and Bliss buildings in downtown Canton today!  It was a great opportunity to see historic preservation up-close. The House will be taking up tax reform this year, and I hope we can continue the historic preservation tax credits to help revitalize our nation's downtown and historic neighborhoods.

ICYMI - I got to see the renovations of the Onesta and Bliss buildings and how historic preservation tax credits help revitalize neighborhoods while continuing local legacies. http://www.cantonrep.com/news/20170707/gibbs-tax-credits-helping-to-rebuild-downtown-canton
Honored to stop by Massillon's Relay for Life this morning and offer some words of encouragement to everyone participating!

Below is an update from the Uniontown Police Chief on the Uniontown officer who was shot in the line of duty.  While he is out of surgery, he will require more medical treatment. Please pray for a speedy recovery for the injured officer and keep his family in your thoughts.

It was an honor to present the Congressional Award Bronze Medal earlier today to Trent Beer of Richland County. Trent is active in his community, he is an excellent student and a participant in his local 4H.  Trent's commitment to his community is an example for all of us.  Congratulations, Trent!

I stopped by the 179th Airlift Wing yesterday to get an update on their recent missions and hear directly from them as Congress considers military funding levels for the next year. I am always impressed by the men and women of the 179th. They perform their duty with honor and dedication to the protection of their fellow citizens and the Constitution.

Ohio's premiums have increased by 86% since 2013. 20 Ohio counties will have no insurance options on the Obamacare exchange. So how do we fix it? Americans need more options, not fewer. We need to incorporate free market principles that will actually lower the costs of healthcare while protecting people with pre-existing conditions.
Great to meet advocates from University Hospitals yesterday to discuss their children's health programs!

Last week, we passed the National Defense Authorization Act, which sets the priorities for our national security.  Keeping America safe is our top priority. That is why we’re increasing the size of our military, making sure our troops are properly trained, and investing in maintenance of essential equipment. We ask so much of the men and women of our Armed Forces. They need support for their families and on the battlefield.  We are also implementing reforms that will help the Pentagon save money in their procurement procedures and administrative processes. This legislation increases Congressional oversight of contracts, opens up the ability for Defense officials to use commercial websites like Amazon for procurement, and eliminates redundant contracts and management systems. The American people deserve a strong military focused on its mission while also acting as good stewards of taxpayer dollars.  I am proud to support our servicemen and servicewomen with this important legislation.

I am honored to be recognized by FreedomWorks today as a recipient of their Freedom Fighter Award. Ronald Reagan once said "Freedom is never more than one generation away from extinction." We have to fight for and defend our God-given freedoms every day. I am proud to be a part of that fight and thank FreedomWorks for being an advocate for personal liberty and limited government.

Senator John McCain is an American hero. His military service and bravery at the hands of unspeakable cruelty shows just how tough he is. Please keep John, Cindy, and their entire family in your prayers as he battles cancer.

Very sad news today of Ralph Regula's passing. Ralph was a friend and mentor. He was a dedicated public servant who cared deeply for his fellow Ohioans. Ralph will be sorely missed. My wife and I offer his family our condolences.

This Monday, I'll be hosting another Live Phone Forum and you can sign up to participate! We'll be starting around 7:15, so if you would like to receive a call to join in, click on the link below and sign up! The deadline to sign up is Monday at 9AM.

Last Friday, the Ohio Flags of Honor Memorial was in Massillon to remember and honor the brave Ohioans who lost their lives in service in Afghanistan, Iraq, and the War on Terrorism. My office was proud to attend this solemn ceremony and recognize the memory of patriots we lost.
Tonight, I'll be leading a Special Order to honor former Congressman Ralph Regula. You can watch on c-span.org at 7:30 PM

Thank you to Pat Tiberi, Rep. Steve Stivers, Bob Latta, Rep. Steve Chabot, and Representative Marcy Kaptur for speaking earlier this week for our special order to remember our good friend, former Congressman Ralph Regula. He made a lasting impact on us, on the House as an institution, and on Northeast Ohio. Ralph will be missed.
Tragic and heartbreaking news out of Columbus at the Ohio State Fair. Please pray for everyone involved, especially those injured and the family of the person who lost his life.
#TBT to 2011 when Scott MacFarlane and I spoke about my introduction of the Recreational Lands Self-Defense Act!

The Small Business Administration will be hosting a Regulatory Reform Roundtable next week, August 3rd in Cleveland. SBA's Office of Advocacy is a watchdog and advocate for small businesses and is conducting roundtables across the country to work with small business owners to identify federal red tape making it difficult to do business. If you are the owner of a small business and would like to participate, please sign up in the link below!

Congratulations to Echoing Hills for celebrating their 50th anniversary this weekend! Echoing Hills hosts and facilitates summer camps for those with developmental disabilities in an effort to encourage them to reach the fullest potential.

I had a great time this morning stopping at Project REBUILD, Canton’s Youthbuild program that gives low-income young people the opportunity to work towards a GED and learn valuable skills while giving back to the community by helping build affordable housing.  This is a great program that gives young men and women the chance to reach beyond their current circumstances, get their education, and make a better life for themselves and their family.

Big thanks to the Coshocton Rotary for the invitation to speak to the club this afternoon in beautiful Roscoe Village! It was a great conversation talking about some of what's happening in Washington. As always, it's good to see my friend, Coshocton Mayor Steve Mercer.

I was happy to join Congressman Jim Jordan this morning in Lorain County to speak with local officials and give an update on what we're working on in Washington to give communities the opportunity to thrive.

The vast majority of VA employees are committed to their mission of providing care for veterans. The few who do things like create secret wait lists, falsify records, or even show up to operating tables intoxicated stain the reputation of those dedicated workers. That's why we passed the VA Accountability And Whistleblower Protection Act. It empowers the VA Secretary to take action against those bad actors and protects the whistleblowers who are doing the right thing.

This Monday, the VFW Post 1079 in Elyria will host a memorial service for and celebrate the life of Fire Controlman 1st Class Gary Leo Rehm Jr., who died saving his shipmates after his vessel, the USS Fitzgerald, collided with a merchant ship off the coast of Japan this past June.  Please click on the link below if you would like to attend.

Simplifying and modernizing our tax code is incredibly important, and not just for small businesses. Families can find the tax code extremely complicated, especially when it comes to using school to improve their lives. Education-based tax benefits can be confusing and complicated. You can learn more throughout August from Committee on Ways and Means.
Just last month, we passed the funding bill for our military, the Department of Energy, and appropriated $1.6 billion for the construction of a wall on our southern border.

One thing I like to say is when a business owner or a non-profit administrator comes across a new government regulation, they should be able to say "This makes sense, we ought to do this." Too often they're forced to comply with regulations that are too costly, contradictory to other rules, or just don't make a lot of sense. Some regulations can have a major economic impact, and the total cost of federal regulations cost the economy nearly $2 trillion in 2012 according to a survey by the National Association of Manufacturers. That's why we passed the REINS Act earlier this year. It requires that major regulations, those that cost the economy $100 million or more, come to Congress for an up or down vote.
Today is National Purple Heart Day. Thank you to the brave men and women injured while serving our nation.

For too long, unelected bureaucrats have had unchecked power regulating nearly every aspect of our economy. These burdensome regulations are costing us jobs and putting pressure on families who are already struggling to make ends meet. The Regulatory Accountability Act requires federal agencies to choose the least costly option when finalizing a new regulation. I am a strong advocate of a regulatory environment that is commonsense, that encourages job growth, and unleashes the entrepreneurial and innovative spirit of the American economy.  Small business owners and people running non-profit organizations should not have to agonize over the maze of red tape and the alphabet soup of federal agencies.

Earlier this year, the House passed the Midnight Rules Relief Act, which allows Congress to pull back regulations as a group that get rushed through in the waning days of a presidential administration.  Restoring appropriate oversight and approval of the government's regulatory power is important to the separation of powers and ensuring our economy thrives for small businesses and families.

So many veterans have a unique story to tell about their time in the Armed Forces, whether it’s a funny story from basic training, a touching memory about a fellow service member, or the experience of coming home after combat.  The Veterans History Project gives them the opportunity to teach history from their perspective.  My office will be at the MAPS Air Museum from 12 noon until 4 PM next Wednesday, August 16th for a recording session of the Library of Congress’ Veterans History Project (VHP). The VHP collects and preserves the personal stories of American war veterans.  If you or a loved one served in the U.S. military and would like to participate next Wednesday, please call my Ashland office at 419-207-0650.

This weekend's violence in Charlottesville, and the hate that fueled it, is antithetical to America and our common values. It has no place in our nation. I pray for the families of those injured or killed and hope justice is served against those who perpetrated such awful criminal acts.
Thank you to OMEGA for inviting me to speak to the group yesterday. We were able to talk about infrastructure investments, economic development, and the importance of local government.

It was an honor meeting the veterans who participated in our recording session for the Veterans History Project yesterday. It's vital to record and preserve their personal accounts for future generations of Americans. Special thanks to MAPS Air Museum for hosting us!

It was an honor to present Army Veteran Ernest Wines with an array of service medals he was awarded and that he and his family have been trying to obtain for many years. Mr Wines served his country with honor and distinction and he deserves the opportunity to proudly display them. My office was proud to assist in ensuring he received them. Please thank Ernest Wines for his service.

Though many in America will only see a partial eclipse today, it's still important to know how to safely view the solar eclipse. NASA has some tips on how to do that. Remember, do NOT look directly at the eclipse. It can still permanently damage your eyes!

Yesterday I had the opportunity to tour Arconic in Canton where they engineer titanium products. I also got to speak with some of their employees regarding the issues they're most concerned about. Those two large tubes are titanium ingots and they weigh 21,000 pounds EACH!

Last week, after I had the honor of presenting Ernest Wines with his service medals, I toured the new Stark Veterans Service Commission office on Wise Ave NW. It's an impressive facility with a great staff. If you're a Stark County veteran and need assistance, we are happy to work with the Stark VSC on your behalf.

Thank you to the Ohio Propane Gas Association and Linden's Propane for the tour yesterday. For the propane industry, winter preparation starts in the hot days of August. Frank Edwards of Linden Propane showed me what they do to get their company and their customers ready for cold weather. #WinterIsComing

Had a great tour and a very productive discussion today at Pegasus Farm in Hartville for our Veterans Roundtable. Pegasus does some incredible work for veterans and persons with disabilities through equine activities coupled with social and vocational support. Thank you to Pegasus, the Ohio Dept of Veterans Services, and Stark VSC for helping with today's roundtable!
If you live in or near Knox County and would like to donate blood today, stop by the YMCA in Mount Vernon between 12 and 5!
Last night we welcomed home the most recent Holmes Wayne Honor Trip in Shreve. It is a privilege to meet these brave Americans!
Spent the lunch hour with the Massillon WestStark Chamber today. Thank you for the opportunity to speak!
Thank you, Jane, for all that you've done for Ashland County veterans! Good luck and enjoy your well-deserved retirement!
Had a great discussion yesterday at the Massillon WestStark Chamber after visiting the Massillon LifeCare Family Health and Dental Center!
Had a great time with NFIB Ohio this afternoon in Stark County. We talked about the regulatory and tax barriers preventing small businesses from expanding operations and hiring more employees.
Great to stop by the Stark County Fair earlier today to thank all the incredible volunteers and employees who make the fair possible.

It's that time of the year: school is starting! Thank you to St Ambrose in Brunswick for having me in to speak to your 8th grade class about government, civics, and the role of Congress.  It was great to also see Brunswick Mayor Ron Falconi!

Earlier today, I hosted a small business roundtable with the Greater Medina Chamber to talk about health care reform and tax reform. It was a great conversation and I got a lot of input on how Washington can create an economic climate that unleashes the power of small businesses and entrepreneurs.

Economic growth isn't just about tax reform. Yes, we need to lower rates and make America more competitive globally. But we also need to ensure our federal assistance programs don't penalize families looking to improve their circumstances. No one should have to turn down a raise or refuse extra hours at a job at the risk of completely losing access to assistance. We need a more graduated scale to encourage work while still providing the help people need!
NA

If you're in or near Coshocton County and are looking for a new job opportunity, head over to the Lake Park Pavilion tomorrow for Ohio Means Jobs Coshocton County's Annual Employment Expo. Dozens of employers will be in attendance!

"Farmers across the country are using small drones to collect data on crop health, soil quality, and hydrologic information. This data will help them with precision planting, increasing their yield and being responsible stewards of the environment. Another emerging area for drone use is in disaster relief and the insurance industry. In the immediate aftermath of tornados, hurricanes or other natural disasters, different types of infrastructure are being inspected before being brought back online. Drones can make it safer for first responders and emergency personnel to inspect downed power lines, ensure structural safety of bridges and roads, or search for survivors."
Good luck to Stark County's own Sarah Clapper as she competes in the Miss America pageant!
Glad to hear Richland County will be getting assistance from the Ohio Attorney General to help combat opioid abuse.

Sixteen years ago today, our nation changed forever. While September 11, 2001 brought forth unimaginable pain and terror, it also brought out the best of America. God bless the victims, their families, the first responders who ran toward the danger, and everyone impacted by 9-11.
Don't forget to follow me on Instagram! This is my intern, Ryan's last week with the office. He'll be taking over my Instagram account this week. Follow him in the link below! #InternTakeover

I'm proud to work with Representative Marcy Kaptur on our efforts to protect Ohio's and America's aviation jobs! The airline industry competes globally and when Gulf countries like Qatar and UAE prop up their airlines with government subsidies, that hurts American works in the aviation and airline industry. We're asking the Trump Administration to enforce #OpenSkies agreements.

This morning I had the opportunity to speak to the AgriPOWER and Young Ag Professionals groups. They are in Washington for the Leadership Experience program. As a former young ag professional myself, I know how important it is to engage your representatives on issues important to agriculture. I applaud these young men and women for their advocacy of agriculture!
September 14th, 2001 - President George W Bush at Ground Zero speaking to the first responders.

Last month, I hosted a recording session for the Library of Congress' Veterans History Project in Stark County. It was an incredible success with over a dozen veterans participating! This month, we'll be conducting interviews in Ashland County on September 22nd. We will be at my Ashland District Office at 110 Cottage Street from 9:30 to 4PM. Please call 419-207-0650 to schedule a time to participate.

I was happy to be in Canton this morning for the groundbreaking ceremony of the HART Center, a detox and rehabilitation facility that will serve the Stark County area for addiction services. It was great to meet Elizabeth Lenzy of the Lenzy Family Institute, the organization building the HART Center. If we can help divert those with addiction problems to treatment, we can help save and strengthen families and improve our communities.
Here's the Canton Repository article about yesterday's groundbreaking ceremony for the HART Center, scheduled to open next June.

The recent devastation in the South from Hurricanes Harvey and Irma is a reminder that even when there's sufficient notice, emergencies can happen.  To help prepare for unexpected emergencies, FEMA has a smartphone app with preparation tips, information on disaster resources, and assist responders by crowdsourcing photographs in disaster areas.  You can download the app for your iPhone or Android device in the link below.

Last night I was at the Tuscarawas County Fair. I got to speak with Ryan from WJER about what Congress has on its plate for the rest of September. The House has taken the lead on many big issues this year. Now, it’s time for the Senate to act.

Proud to announce that the Drug Free Stark County community coalition is receiving a $125,000 grant through the Drug-Free Communities Program!  Stark County, like the rest of Ohio, is experiencing the effects of the rising opioid epidemic and its devastating impact on families and neighborhoods. Overcoming this crisis requires a comprehensive community effort to target the root of the problem before it takes hold. Working with youth to prevent and treat drug abuse is an important part of that, and I congratulate the Drug Free Stark County community coalition on their grant award.

Thank you to Ashland University for hosting us this morning for a Roundtable Discussion on Agriculture and next year’s Farm Bill. We had representatives from many of Ohio’s commodity groups. Agriculture is a big part of Ohio’s economy and we want to make sure next year’s Farm Bill works for farmers AND taxpayers.

Every year Americans are forced to go through the laborious process of filing their taxes. Some estimates show Americans spend $99 billion a year on tax compliance. We need to make it fair and simple for American families.

It's great to see SCORE, a resource partner with the Small Business Administration, work with the Canton Regional Chamber of Commerce to help guide and mentor growing small businesses with an emphasis on female-led businesses. If you have just started a business and would like to utilize SCORE's resources, you can visit https://www.score.org.

I had a great time this morning chatting with the Wilmington College Collegiate Farm Bureau. They had excellent questions about agriculture and trade policy. Thanks to students like these, the future of the Ag industry is bright!

House Republicans are keeping our commitment to provide real tax relief for the American people. We are working to make the tax system simpler and fairer for families so they can keep more of their paycheck.  From simplifying and reducing the number of tax brackets to doubling the standard deduction, middle-class families will benefit from the ideas in this framework.  You can read more at fairandsimple.gop
I had a great time yesterday chatting with a group of Ohioans in DC talking about their experiences and regulatory challenges raising deer.
Steve Scalise is back at the House for the first time since he was injured in an attack while practicing for the Congressional Baseball Game. I am so glad to see Steve back!

Jennifer Kiko has been working in my Canton office since July 2014. She is a tireless and fearless person with unstoppable enthusiasm for her work and compassion for the people she meets. While I am sad to say this is Jennifer's last week working for the people of Ohio's Seventh District, I know she'll continue to be a positive force for all of us as she transitions into the important work of addiction and recovery services. Good luck, Jenn!
In the aftermath of disaster and destruction, the Ohio Air National Guard steps up time and time again. The 179th Airlift Wing is on its way to the US Virgin Islands for relief efforts.

Yesterday was the Walk to End Alzheimer’s in Knox County. I was honored to attend and provide some encouragement for everyone participating. The American medical research industry is the best in the world, making giant leaps in understanding diseases like Alzheimer’s. With passionate local advocates like in Knox County, we’ll be able to push medical research for Alzheimer’s closer to a cure.

As we all woke up to the terrible news of senseless violence in Las Vegas last night, it is a reminder of how precious life is. Please join me in praying for the victims, their families, and the first responders who run towards the danger every day.

Thank you to the Lorain County Sheriff's Office for organizing a prescription drug turn-in day at the end of the month. If you have leftover prescription medication and would like to ensure their safe and secure disposal, you can take them to a number of locations in Lorain County on October 28th. Find out where in the article below.

Tonight, the House passed the Pain-Capable Unborn Child Protection Act, also known as Micah's Law. The majority of Americans favor a ban on abortions at 20 weeks, the stage at which an unborn child has the biological ability to feel pain. Yet the United States is one of only seven nations in the world to allow elective abortions at that stage of development. This bill provides protections for lives that science has proven viable and capable of feeling the abortion being performed on them. We as a nation must recognize our responsibility to protect the most vulnerable among us and provide every life the opportunity to thrive.
October is Down Syndrome Awareness Month. I was happy to meet the group from Ohio representing the National Down Syndrome Society yesterday.
I’m honored to receive the Friend of Ag award from Holmes County Farm Bureau last night! Thank you for the invitation to address the group to give an update on agriculture policy in Washington.

I applaud the Trump Administration’s efforts to reverse the Clean Power Plan, another part of Obama’s war on coal.  The United States has made great strides in reducing emissions in the last 40 years, and the CPP would have cost billions while providing little to no benefits. The hard-working men and women of Ohio’s coal-producing region deserve a chance at a good living without government bureaucrats making it difficult to provide for their families.  The President understands that affordable and reliable energy is what drives a growing economy. The EPA’s announcement will allow working and middle-class families to spend less of their paycheck on utility bills.

ICYMI - Yesterday, I sent a letter to the Trump Administration urging Secretary of Commerce Wilbur Ross to complete his department's investigation into cheap foreign steel imports and their impact on national security. The longer they delay an enforcement action, the more time foreign competitors have to dump subsidized steel in the US market.

Thank you to Jade Davis and Will Friedman of the Port of Cleveland for stopping by yesterday. The Port is so important to Northeast Ohio’s economy and it’s vital we keep the Cuyahoga River properly dredged and open for business.

The President did the right thing today in announcing a new strategy regarding Iran. The details of the nuclear deal are insufficient in terms of preventing Iranian access to nuclear weapons, as restrictions from the deal will soon be sunsetting. It is not in the United States' interests to reward a regime that provides financial and material support for terrorists and continues a hostile and belligerent posture towards our allies.

Congratulations to Steve Coon on his lifetime achievement award from Heritage Ohio. Earlier this year he showed me some of his projects in Canton and how they’re rehabbing and preserving historic buildings. It’s incredible work that honors the architectural history and beauty of Canton.

Thank you to Jeromesville Mayor Randy Spade for the invitation to last night’s village council meeting and the opportunity to address the council. Mayor Spade invited me to show how Jeromesville is working to re-invigorate their community.

I appreciate the invitation from Mr. Gottke to speak with his AP Government class at Mount Vernon High School yesterday.  We had an informative discussion on government and politics. Every time I meet young Ohioans with an interest in public policy, I know that our nation’s future generation of leaders are taking their education and responsibilities very seriously.
Last night I had the honor of speaking to the Ohio Western Reserve chapter of the Military Officers Association of America. We had a productive conversation about defense spending and VA reforms.

It was good day in Bolivar with the ribbon cutting on the Bolivar Dam rehabilitation! I’m proud that we’ve engaged to Army Corps on multiple projects, just like this one, that are so important to our communities.

On Saturday, I attended a ribbon cutting for the First North Building in Massillon. It’s a great project to help bring more businesses and economic opportunity to downtown Massillon. It was a pleasure seeing Mayor Catazaro-Perry and Massillon WestStark Chamber of Commerce President Ted Herncane there!

In the 30 years since the last major reforms to the federal tax code, our economy has gone through radical changes. We need tax reform that reflects those changes, that makes it fairer and simpler for families, and makes it easier for American businesses to compete in today’s global economy.
Here's some more information about the First North Building in Massillon. The building will attract more business to downtown and the artwork surrounding it honors Massillon's history and heritage.

Yesterday I joined my colleagues Pat Tiberi, Rep. Steve Stivers, and Rep Sam Graves at the Transportation Research Center Inc to take a look at some of their groundbreaking work on vehicle testing. It is the largest facility of its kind in the United States.

I applaud President Donald J. Trump's announcement today creating a pilot program for testing unmanned aerial systems, aka drones, in the US. Unmanned flight is the next generation in American aviation. It's important for everyone involved to work together and craft sensible and safe rules for the operation of drones in American airspace. My DC office was able to meet the veterans from the Veterans Honor Bus to DC - Ashland County OH on Friday to welcome them to Washington and thank them for their service. Here they are at the World War II Memorial. Ronald Reagan once said “Freedom is never more than one generation away from extinction.” It is the brave men and women like those on this trip who defended it from extinction. We will forever be grateful for their service.
Thank you to all those who served in the United States military. We would not enjoy the freedoms we have today without you.

We had a lively discussion and some of their stories reminded me of the years I spent raising hogs.

More than 3/4 of people who file taxes in the 7th District use the standard deduction. Our tax plan nearly DOUBLES it. The time is NOW for #TaxReform that provides real tax relief for middle class and working families.
Congratulations to my friend and former colleague in the Ohio General Assembly, Dave Hall for his appointment as USDA's Ohio Director for the Office of Rural Development!

The Tax Foundation analyzed the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act and determined in Ohio alone, we'll see over 36,000 new jobs and a $2,375 increase in income for median households. The status quo of higher taxes and special interest loopholes is unsustainable. It's time for change: tax reform that delivers relief for middle class families.

Yesterday, 20 Ohioans were inducted into the Ohio Veterans Hall of Fame. David Dilly of Coshocton County was among them. He served in the Air Force during the Vietnam War and after his service, continued to help the veterans of Ohio as a member of AMVETS, the VFW, American Legion, the Coshocton County Veterans Council, and many more. He currently serves as a commissioner for the Coshocton County VSO and was instrumental in the Coshocton County KIA Memorial Bridge Project which named 96 bridges in the county after fallen heroes from the area. Mr. Dilly's accomplishments are not just seen in the groups he has joined, but also in the lives he's changed.  My staff was on hand to honor and congratulate him for his induction into the Ohio Veterans Hall of Fame. David Dilly is an American hero and a role model for young men and women. Thank you for your service to our country and your community.

Happy to be in Dover this morning for the unveiling of the downtown clock. A great group of local organizations came together to make this happen. I’m proud to represent cities like Dover, which takes such pride in their community.
