We're voting on the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act tomorrow! This is about making taxes fairer and simpler for families and spurring economic growth. The typical family of 4, making $59,000/year, can expect a $1,182 tax cut.

Here's the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act by the numbers: 76.4% - Current percentage of people in Ohio’s 7th District who file taxes using the standard deduction.   $12,000/$24,000 – the nearly doubled standard deductions for single/joint filers under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, enabling more individuals to use the standard deduction.  $1182 – Size of tax cut for a typical family of four making $59,000/year  $1,600 – Amount of the expanded Child Tax Credit in the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act  33,736 – The number of NEW full time jobs the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act will create in Ohio according to the Tax Foundation’s analysis

This morning my friend and former colleague Bill Harris passed away. He and I served in the Ohio legislature together. He was a warm and friendly person who loved God, his country, and his family.  My deepest condolences to his family in this difficult time.
Thank you to the Kiwanis Club in Mount Vernon for the invitation to address the group this afternoon. I appreciated all the questions!

Sergeant Jesse Reese, a resident of Dover, Ohio, was a B-17 tail gunner during WWII. He flew over 35 combat missions, with over 280 combat flight hours in the European Theater. He was assigned to the Army Air Corps’ 337th Bombardment Squadron, of the 96th Bombardment Group. His plane was hit by 20mm shells on December 31st, 1944 while flying over Germany. As a result, the plane broke formation and became a lone target. Reese repelled enemy attacks from his tail gunner position and the B-17 was able to make an emergency landing. While several crew members were wounded, no lives were lost thanks in part to his efforts.  Last week, Sergeant Reese was awarded the French Legion of Honor by the Consul General of France, Guillaume Lacroix. The Legion of Honor is the highest award given by the French Government and was started in 1802 by Napoleon. My office was proud to recognize Sergeant Reese’s award with proclamation from my office. Thank you for your bravery and service, Sergeant!

Today the Transportation and Infrastructure Committee held a hearing on the status and future of unmanned aerial vehicles, aka drones, in commercial airspace. We'll be seeing more and more drones in the skies in the coming years and the FAA should take a look at modifying line of sight regulations, especially in the energy industry and in disaster relief efforts.

The system failed the Steinle family. Her killer had been deported 5 times previously and San Francisco police did not cooperate with federal immigration authorities in their request to detain him. It's cases like these that reinforce the need for stronger enforcement of illegal immigration laws.

It's simple: If you're legally allowed and licensed to carry a concealed firearm in your home state, you should be able to do the same in any other state that permits concealed carry as long as you observe the related laws of those states.  I am proud to have supported the protection of law-abiding citizens' second amendment rights.

Today I was able to help the American Red Cross in their project to send Christmas cards to troops stationed overseas during the holidays. While they may be far from friends and family, I hope we could contribute even just a little to bring them some holiday cheer while they serve their nation.

Like I said last year in an op-ed for Townhall.com, the consequences of an unbridled regulatory regime are not always obvious. There is no “regulation compliance” item on your dinner bill or supermarket receipt.  The phalanx of bureaucrats that populate regulatory agencies have acted as a hidden fourth branch of government.  A sensible regulatory approach that does not hinder the economic engine of our entrepreneurs is essential to keeping America safe, strong, and prosperous.
Next week we'll be voting on the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act. It doubles the standard deduction, doubles the child tax credit, and kills Obamacare's individual mandate.
Congratulations to Century National Bank and Olde Town Realty in Coshocton County for their ribbon cutting last week!

Today is the day we bring real tax relief to middle and working-class families in Ohio and across the country. With the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, the typical family of four will see a $2,059 tax cut.  It's time to change the status quo and lower tax rates across the board so people can keep more of their hard earned money.

Some people seem to forget that this is your money in the first place, not the government's. I'm looking forward to the President signing The #TaxCutsAndJobsAct into law, bringing real tax relief for working and middle-class families.

Some people said the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act was "Armageddon".  Middle-class families and American workers are going to see larger paychecks and see the real benefits of tax relief. That doesn't sound like Armageddon to me.  Just yesterday, we saw:  • Fifth Third Bank has announced that they will pay more than 13,500 employees a $1,000 bonus and will raise the minimum wage for their workers to $15 dollar per hour. The bonuses will not be provided to senior managers and top executives.  • AT&T said they will be providing $1,000 bonuses to 200,000 employees and are investing an additional $1 billion in the United States in 2018.  • Boeing will invest $300 million in workplace development, facilities, and charitable giving endeavors — such as employee gift-match programs.  • Wells Fargo also announced that they will be increasing their minimum wage to $15 and providing $400 million in philanthropic contributions in 2018.  • Comcast is giving $1,000 bonuses to 100,000+ employees and is investing $50 billion in broadband infrastructure.
Interesting analysis by the Tax Policy Center showing 80% of all households getting a tax cut with the bill that the President just signed into law. The average tax cut will be over $2,000!

Following up on the data from the Tax Policy Center, here is the Tax Foundation's analysis. It provides a range of scenarios for how the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, which the President signed into law yesterday, will affect them.
